title: HMCS Tuna
text:
HMCS "Tuna was a commissioned <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Navy">Royal Canadian Navy</a> (RCN) that served during the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. Built as the high-speed civilian <a href="yacht">yacht</a> Tarantula", the vessel was one of several converted yachts the RCN used during the war. Following the war, the ship was discarded and stripped.
Design and description.
Originally constructed as a civilian yacht, "Tarantula" was among the first <a href="Steam%20turbine">turbine</a>-powered private yachts. The hull was similar to the torpedo boats that <a href="Yarrow%20Shipbuilders">Yarrow Shipbuilders</a> had constructed for the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>. The ship was modeled on , the first turbine-powered ship. The yacht had a <a href="Gross%20register%20tonnage">gross register tonnage (GRT)</a> of 124 and was <a href="Length%20overall">long</a> with a <a href="Beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="Draft%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The ship had a maximum speed of thanks to her turbine engines.
Construction and career.
Built by Yarrow Shipbuilders in the United Kingdom, "Tarantula" was ordered by <a href="William%20Kissam%20Vanderbilt%20II">W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.</a> and <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> in 1902. Vanderbilt used the yacht for commuting in and around <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
In August 1914, <a href="John%20Ross%20%28industrialist%29">Jack Ross</a>, a Canadian industrialist and millionaire, purchased "Tarantula" from Vanderbilt. At the time the United States had forbidden the sale of any vessel capable of being used by those nations fighting in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> at the time. Ross arranged for her to be fitted out in the United States in secret and arrived at <a href="Halifax%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Halifax, Nova Scotia</a> on 10 September after sailing with her civilian crew. Ross sold the ship for $1 to the RCN and offered to re-purchase the ship if the ship was still functional at war's end.
She was designated as a torpedo boat after the installation of two <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s and a gun. The ship was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 5 December 1914 as HMCS "Tuna", with Ross in command. The ship was assigned to patrol duties based out of Halifax, she was a common sight in <a href="Bedford%20Basin">Bedford Basin</a>.
In July 1916, "Tuna" underwent an overhaul at <a href="Sorel%2C%20Quebec">Sorel, Quebec</a>. On 10 May 1917 "Tuna" was <a href="Paid%20Off%20%28Upon%20Decommissioning%20a%20Ship%29">paid off</a> due to an irreparable engine mount fracture. She was sold for salvage in June 1918, and stripped. Her <a href="Hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> remained in Halifax's <a href="Northwest%20Arm">Northwest Arm</a> until the 1930s.
